captions.text:
Look, Yahtzee, it&#39;s Silent Hill f! Ooh! 
A new game set in Silent Hill? ...No. But

it is called Silent Hill. Oh, right. Perhaps 
you&#39;ll be interested in buying my new book.

It&#39;s a bloody historical account of the Rwandan 
genocide, and it&#39;s called The Little Elephant

Who Went Shopping because names don&#39;t mean 
anything in your little world. Oh, shut up,

Past Yahtzee. We agreed to stop moaning about 
blatant IP milking as long as half-decent games

get some exposure out of it. And you know 
what? Story and setting aside, the gameplay

of Silent Hill fff does Silent Hill fffeel more 
authentically like a classic Silent Hill game

than anything since Silent Hill 4, I&#39;d say. I 
mean, yes, we have the inevitable RE4-style,

glued to the gluteus maximus third-person camera, 
which I guess is just what horror games are now,

but otherwise, it&#39;s got the foggy town, the 
puzzles, the atmosphere, the UFO ending,

a faint whiff of gynophobia, the bringing down 
of big bits of pipe upon fucked-up monsters with

fairly blatant symbolism and their bums 
hanging out, and the wandering around,

filling out a map while roughly 80 to 90% of 
the doors you try to open aren&#39;t actually real

and were presumably put in to fool the 
occupational health and safety people.

In Silent Hill ffforget about every previous 
game, we play as Hinako, a schoolgirl—for what

is Japanese culture if not one harrowing thing 
happening to a schoolgirl after another?—in a

small Japanese town in the &#39;60s. She has a Silent 
Hill ffffight with her parents and runs off to

hang out with her Silent Hill ffffriends: boy 
best friend who&#39;s obviously in love with her,

girl best friend who&#39;s obviously in love with 
boy best friend, and of course the wacky one

who&#39;s in love with, er... the concept of 
third-wheeling. But just as the game has

reached maximum dippy high school romance manga 
vibes, wacky friend suddenly dies horribly,

exploding into red slime, and Hinako has to 
run away from a murderous fog while getting

chased by bloody mannequin monsters with knives, 
and I&#39;m like, &quot;Fucking hell, talk about turning

on a yen.&quot; And so Hinako&#39;s overall goal is 
presented: get the fuck out of dodge, but of

course it&#39;s not as simple as that. A while later, 
I&#39;m in a dungeon themed around a wedding chapel

as I smack the tits off a monster resembling 
a giant, tortured pregnant woman, and I think,

&quot;Hang on; call me paranoid, but I&#39;m starting 
to pick up on a faint subtext going on here.&quot;

But more on that later. What surprised me about 
Silent Hill effff is its Silent Hill emphhhhasis

on combat. The mechanics are quite complex. 
Press for light attack; hold for strong attack;

keep an eye on your stamina bar; you can 
counter, and if you hold down the Focus button,

the counters get easier, but be careful because 
that depletes your Sanity bar, which—or I could

just run past everything, game. That&#39;s an option. 
&#39;Cause there&#39;s no benefit to killing everything,

especially with the ever-welcome inclusion 
of weapon degradation, sarcasm quotes,

and when you press the dodge button, Hinako 
fucking flies across the room like she&#39;s got

afterburners for tits, so escaping stuff is easy. 
Until it isn&#39;t. There are boss fights, of course;

some towards the end that feel a bit out of place 
and like they&#39;d be more at home in Elden Ring,

and for some reason, every time you run into that 
aforementioned tortured pregnant woman monster,

it locks off the exits and 
you&#39;re forced to fight it,

and it&#39;s the only regular monster that does that. 
Not sure why. Maybe the game wants to really,

really make sure you&#39;re picking up on the subtle 
metaphor at work there. Certainly not because

it&#39;s fun or interesting to fight; it&#39;s about as 
engaging as hammering nails into a sofa cushion.

Puzzles are a mixed bag. Some are quite good, 
like the one where you figure out locker codes.

And some of them are Silent Hill phhhenomenally 
bad. I&#39;m thinking of the one where you need to

hang a calendar on an unmarked section of one 
of several Silent Hill ffffeatureless walls,

and to figure out which, you just have 
to smear yourself across the environment,

mashing the &quot;use&quot; button like you&#39;re looking for 
secret doors in Wolfenstein 3D. And then there&#39;s

the scarecrow puzzles. It&#39;s possible they were 
poorly translated; I ended up having to brute

force try every scarecrow until I found the right 
ones; the clues offered might as well have been a

selection of farm animal noises and flatulence. 
And while we&#39;re nitpicking, the game has the

traditional Silent Hill problem of loading you 
down with too many items—who the fuck needs items

that restore stamina, incidentally? That shit 
comes back by itself if you just breathe in and

out for a bit—but fortunately, the stringent 
limited inventory kinda cancels that problem

out. Fighting annoyances with annoyances. How 
efficient. Like when my dog eats his own sick.

But enough sickpicking. Let me get down to 
the Silent Hill ffffocal point of the matter.

The only question that matters when it comes 
to horror games is, &quot;Was it scary?&quot; And yes,

it was scary and creepy and disturbing with 
several particularly harrowing moments that

stuck with me and I&#39;ll no doubt be thinking 
about the next time I eat barbecue ribs. Hooray,

we figured it out. That said, I was left 
disappointed by the overall story. Which

is officially as far I can go without spoilers. 
To quickly summarize for those planning to play

the game, there&#39;s some iffy gameplay 
choices, some great memorable moments,

but it kind of comes apart on the wider analysis. 
Right, I will now signal entry to the spoilery

bit of the video by making a noise like a walrus 
riding a roller coaster. Okay. It becomes clear as

you progress through the plot that you&#39;re actually 
alternating between two versions of Hinako. One&#39;s

stuck in her foggy hometown, hanging out with 
her two mates who never seem to get the memo

that they&#39;re NOT in a dippy high school romance 
manga, going through reminders of her childhood,

and getting the shit kicked out of her. The 
other Hinako is in a weird metaphorical realm

going through the process of marrying a weird fox 
dude while getting the shit kicked out of her.

And then it turns out one of the Hinakos is the 
entity causing all the problems for the other

Hinako, and after an out-of-place Elden Ring-y 
final boss fight, we get an incredibly shit ending

implying that the entire game was a metaphor for 
the internal struggle of a girl coming to terms

with reaching adulthood. And I felt robbed because 
&quot;entire game was a metaphor&quot; is just &quot;it was all a

dream&quot; with a PhD. Personally, I think it&#39;s a lot 
creepier when you don&#39;t know what&#39;s real and what

isn&#39;t. So when the game goes, &quot;None of it was 
real! Should&#39;ve laid off the over-the-counter

stay awake pills!&quot; all sense of mystery evaporates 
and I lose my investment. &quot;But wait, Yahtz! If

you play through again, you&#39;ll get a different 
ending, some different dialogue, and another,

entirely distinct but equally out-of-place Elden 
Ring-y final boss fight. And you might even get

the ending that has some actual fucking closure 
if you play through the entire game three more

times.&quot; Wow. Silent Hill ffffuck off. I guess 
NieR: Automata does something similar, but that

had fun combat and a nice, juicy bum to admire. 
I&#39;m not down for Silent Hill ffffour playthroughs

worth of awkwardly swinging pipes like a steam 
organ removal specialist on a spiral staircase.

And as for admiring juicy bums, I don&#39;t wanna get 
put on the Silent Hill Sex Offffffenders Register.
